In this short comic, two data workers describe their work impersonating an ‚ÄúAI‚Äù chatbot for a major social media platform. Sleepless nights, penalties for sounding ‚Äútoo human,‚Äù and emotional drain are just a few of the job hazards.

queue.targetText: A hallmark of emotional intelligence, is discernment. I wanna be clear though, emotional intelligence isn‚Äôt just understanding others. It‚Äôs about knowing when to stop making excuses for them. Just because you can empathize with someone‚Äôs behavior, doesn‚Äôt mean you have to keep tolerating it.
queue.context: Perfect TensionLines content: emotional intelligence as boundary-setting, empathy vs tolerance paradox, practical wisdom

queue.targetText:
It's always the same. Unbelievably lazy, derived from minimal thought and hoary old stereotypes, yet presented as the consequence of a rare and profound self-knowledge.

It's like those people who proudly declare, 'I don't believe in the old man with a beard, but I am a very spiritual person.'
queue.context: Sharp critique of lazy self-knowledge claims‚Äîcalls out performative spirituality vs genuine insight

queue.targetText: "To Deleuze, Stoicism was a philosophy that emphasised the importance of life. 'A life' is made up of intensive moments and events, but it can never be separated from the immanence of nature itself." bluelabyrinths.com/2020/10/25/g...
queue.context: Stoicism and immanence‚Äîphilosophy-meets-life, intensity and events, relevant to our themes

queue.targetText:
Same here. I think a lot of these AI proponents on these threads have the energy of ‚Äúdeploy it and figure it out as we go.‚Äù

I make medication for a living. That philosophy would have made me a murderer for following it.

Life-critical technologies are NOT a place to cut safety margins. Ever.
queue.context: Stakes of 'move fast and break things' philosophy‚Äîtension between innovation and responsibility in life-critical contexts
